WELL â€” WOULD YOU RIOT FOR A PAYCHECK?
Why Has the Colour Revolution in Moldova Been Called Off? Colour Revolution in Georgia  
By Stephen Karganovic
This question is rhetorical, of course, because such an event was never scheduled. The properly formulated question is why a classical colour revolution isnâ€™t now in progress in Moldova, after the fraudulent elections that recently took place in that country? The blatantly unfair â€œelectoralâ€ process which resulted in Maia Sanduâ€™s alleged victory, critical to the collective West as its adventure in Ukraine turns into a  debacle, meets all the criteria that trigger a â€œspontaneousâ€ colour revolution of the sort to which we have grown painfully accustomed.

But instead of facing civil turbulence for the dishonestly conducted 3 November Presidential election, on the contrary, fervent NATO and EU advocate and World Economic Forum Young Leader Sandu has been effusively praised and warmly congratulated on her bogus triumph.

At the same time, a concerted attempt to provoke regime change using classical colour revolution instruments is being made in Georgia.

So far, it has fizzled out not for lack of trying but because of the political maturity shown by the Georgian people, who refused to take the bait. The pretext was the allegedly disputed parliamentary election in Georgia, the numerical result of which favouring the governing party (about 54%) and the opposition (45%) roughly corresponds to the contrastingly acceptable outcome in Moldova. What was the crucial difference? It was chiefly the geopolitical orientation of the respective governments that in those elections were up for public approval and the fact that the â€œnon-governmental organisationsâ€ which on command trigger regime change agitation are under the control of collective West intelligence agencies. Those agencies, in turn, and the governments whose instructions they execute, operate not with a factual but a utilitarian concept of what is a fair and free election. If as in Moldova the outcome serves collective Westâ€™s goals the election is fair; if as in Georgia it hinders them, it is fraudulent. Things are quiet in Moldova because local hirelings there were ordered not to stir up public discontent whilst in Georgia they were issued the opposite directive.

The other noteworthy difference is that the egregious irregularities of the electoral process in Moldova are amply documented whilst allegations of similar misconduct in Georgia remain unsupported by any evidence whatsoever. But in the rules based order that hardly matters.

The completely utilitarian nature of the assessments, by Western political institutions and media at least, of whether an election was legitimate or not, is demonstrated by the fact that the large segment of the Moldavian electorate residing in Russia, estimated to number about half a million, were effectively disenfranchised from the voting process. That was accomplished by drastically reducing to just a handful the number of Moldovan polling stations on Russian territory and making available only 10,000 paper ballots (curiously, it did not occur to anyone in Kishinev to use Dominion voting machines instead) to those Moldovan citizens residing in Russia who managed to overcome all obstacles in order to exercise their right to vote.

On the other hand, to stress the Moldovan regimeâ€™s strict adherence to â€œEuropean valuesâ€, no hindrances were placed in the way of the Moldovan diaspora in the European Union to take part in presidential elections in the country to which they may have a connection but where they do not reside. The Moldovan regimeâ€™s calculus was that the bulk of the Moldovans living and employed in the EU have a private interest to not disrupt Moldovaâ€™s European Union accession process, however remote the prospects, because their legal residence in Europe and consequently the jobs they hold there enabling them to send remittances to relatives in impoverished Moldova depend on it. Unlike Moldovans residing in Russia, that segment of the Moldovan diaspora are highly motivated out of economic self-interest to vote for Maia Sandu and her pro-European policies. In the referendum to enshrine the goal of EU accession within the Moldovan Constitution, held under identically unequal conditions and simultaneously with the first round of presidential elections on 20 October, it was the vote of the Moldovan diaspora residing in the EU which enabled the proposed measure to prevail, albeit with a razor-thin margin of a fraction of a single percentage point.

In both instances, the majority of the people actually living in Moldova, who were to be most directly affected by the outcome of the voting, did not support either their governmentâ€™s pro-European Union policy or the election of Western puppet Maia Sandu to the presidency of their country. Results favourable to Western interests were achieved by resorting to corrupt practices and flagrant electoral engineering.

Understandably therefore a colour revolution was not engendered in the aftermath of the recent elections in Moldova, although all the objective conditions from Gene Sharpâ€™s playbook for launching one have been fulfilled. It suffices to recall in this regard one of the fundamental triggers which in the past have led to the overthrow of numerous legitimate governments that were indisposed to bow to the political dictates laid down by arrogant Western hegemons.

Sharpâ€™s doctrine prescribes that a close election result ideally facilitates the task of professionally organised and amply financed colour revolutionaries who are in need of a plausible pretext to mobilise and direct the clueless masses. That is because it lends credibility to the allegation of malfeasance levelled against the targeted â€œregimeâ€ and fuels a sense of grievance among the populace, who supposedly were cheated out of effectively asserting their political will.

Such malfeasance is precisely what happened in Moldova but did not occur in Georgia. But Moldova is covered by a tight and, unlike in Georgia, unsupervised network of Western financed â€œNGOs,â€ which by default exercise a monopoly on disinformation and â€œcivil societyâ€ activities. Consequently, in Moldova there is no movement to denounce flagrant systemic fraud or to challenge the legitimacy of the regime of foreign vassals who base their rule on the simulacrum of authority derived from that fraud. That is because, as we explained, the criteria that are always applied are unabashedly utilitarian; â€œconstructiveâ€ fraud as in Moldova, which serves the interests of the puppeteers, is always proper and irreproachable.

By contrast, honest elections, as in Georgia, which go against the grain are always and irrespective of the factual matrix denounced as fraudulent.

Whoever is endowed with even a modest capacity for political reasoning will easily recognise the crooked game and the malignant rules by which it is being played.

Des violences ont Ã©maillÃ© le weekend de la Toussaint dans plusieurs villes de France. A Rillieux-la-Pape dans le RhÃ´ne, des affrontements ont eu lieu entre des individus et les forces de lâ€™ordre. Plusieurs personnes ont Ã©tÃ© tuÃ©es au cours de diffÃ©rents faits divers Ã  travers le pays.                                     

                 Ã‰lections en Moldavie: portÃ©e par la diaspora, Maia Sandu remporte la prÃ©sidentielle             
«Ce ne sont pas des jeunes qui ont mis le feu à ces bus, mais des voyous, des délinquants. La grande majorité des jeunes de Rillieux-la-Pape veut sâ€™en sortir et prend toute sa place dans la République».
Le maire de la commune de Rillieux-la-Pape, voisine de Lyon, Alexandre Vincendet, a vivement réagi le 2 novembre sur les réseaux sociaux et à la télévision après les violences urbaines qui ont touché sa ville les 31 octobre et 1er novembre au soir.

Ce ne sont pas des jeunes qui ont mis le feu Ã  ces bus, mais des voyous, des dÃ©linquants. La grande majoritÃ© des jeunes de #Rillieuxlapape veut s'en sortir et prend toute sa place dans la RÃ©publique. #sÃ©curitÃ©https://t.co/um2DwKlvM9
— Alexandre VINCENDET (@AlexVincendet) November 2, 2024
L’élu du parti Horizons, qui avait été condamné pour des faits de violences contre son fils de 4 ans, réclame par ailleurs le soutien des parents face aux débordement des jeunes: «soit ils nous aident à faire en sorte que leur enfant rentre dans le droit chemin [â€¦], soit on suspend les aides».
Le 31 octobre au soir plusieurs voitures ont été brûlées dans cette banlieue lyonnaise, qui a déjà été le théâtre de violences urbaines. Le lendemain se sont deux bus qui ont été incendiés, provoquant lâ€™évacuation de riverains. Un policier a également été blessé au visage.
«Y’en a marre de payer pour ces racailles!»
«Honte à ceux qui s’en prennent aux policiers et mettent nos quartiers en danger», a condamné le 2 novembre Tiffany Joncour, député Rassemblement National (RN) du Rhône, apportant son «soutien total aux forces de l’ordre blessées pour nous protéger».
«Rillieux-la-Pape brûle !», s’est alarmé l’eurodéputé RN Matthieu Valet. «Y’en a marre de payer pour ces racailles! Fin des allocations pour les parents de ces délinquants. Expulsion des logements sociaux de ces fauteurs de trouble. Fin de l’excuse de minorité dès 16 ans! Du courage!», a-t-il scandé.

À gauche de l’échiquier politique, le député de La France Insoumise (LFI) du Rhône, Abdelkader Lahmar, a de son côté condamné les actes de violences tout en affirmant être «convaincu que la solution viendra du dialogue».
Poitiers, Rennes, Dijon, Ozoir la Ferrièreâ€¦ une fin de semaine sous le signe de la violence
Aux affrontements survenus à Rillieux-la-Pape, d’autres communes françaises ont vu le week-end prolongé de la Toussaint marqué par des violences.
Dans la nuit du 31 au 1er novembre, dans la Drôme, un jeune homme âgé de 22 ans a été mortellement blessé par balle devant une discothèque à Saint-Péray. Nommé Nicolas, il était dans le même club de rugby que le jeune Thomas, tué à Crépol en novembre 2023. Le président du Rassemblement National Jordan Bardella n’a pas manqué de faire ce rapprochement et de dénoncer: «il est la nouvelle victime de la barbarie quotidienne qui s’abat sur la France».
Le 1er novembre, à Poitiers, un mineur de 15 ans est mort après avoir reçu une balle en pleine tête lors dâ€™une fusillade. Quatre autres jeunes, dont deux de moins de 16 ans, ont été blessés par balles dans cette rixe sur fond de trafic de drogue, qui aurait impliqué «50 à 60 personnes», selon une source policière citée par la presse française.
A Rennes, le 2 novembre, c’est un jeune homme de 19 ans qui a été poignardé à mort dans le quartier de Pontchaillou. Le même jour, un autre homme de 29 ans a été poignardé lors dâ€™une rixe en début de soirée dans le centre-ville.
Dans la nuit du 2 au 3 novembre à Dijon, en Côte-d’Or, c’est un jeune homme qui a été passé à tabac et «laissé pour mort», selon sa mère, «pour au final un téléphone et un portefeuille». 

Enfin, le début de la semaine a également été marqué par des faits de violences. Moldovan Elections â€“ Strange Results Expose Western Hypocrisy AND Double Standards!
by Seth Ferris,Â 
Moldovaâ€™s recent elections, marred by apparent fraud, reveal a country deeply divided over its future. President Maia Sandu, a staunch EU supporter, failed to secure an outright victory, with just 42.45% of the vote in the first round, forcing a runoff and drawing votes largely from the diaspora.

Despite heavy campaigning, Sandu barely eked out a win in a constitutional referendum to enshrine Moldovaâ€™s â€œEuropean Path,â€ with a narrow 50.3% â€œYesâ€ result. Opposition candidate Alexandr Stoianoglo, who initially garnered 25.98%, would have stood a solid chance if other opposition forces had united. The questionable vote count underscores Moldovaâ€™s stark internal rift and raises questions of legitimacy amid Western backing.

Moldovans are not happy about their current governmentâ€™s assault on traditionally friendly ties with Russia

Not suspicious at all, where have we seen that before?

The final result was a razor-thin â€œYesâ€ vote, with 50.3% of voters in favor and 49.7% against, after a â€œlast-minute spikeâ€ in yes votes.

Needless to say, this was not at all a ringing endorsement of either Sandu, who was widely predicted, at least in the west, to cruise home to a first round win, or of the â€œEuropean Pathâ€ and elections that were expected to give a solid result and ensure the stability of the Sandu regime instead show a highly divided population, and almost certainly ensure instability, if not worse, for Moldova.

Moldovans are not happy about their current governmentâ€™s assault on traditionally friendly ties with Russia. Needless to say, Sandu immediately blamed her failure to secure a first round win, and the narrow referendum result, on â€œRussian interferenceâ€ without providing any evidence.

It is of particular concern that nearly 500,000 eligible voters living in Russia were disenfranchised by the provision of only two polling stations in Moscow, and the allocation of only 10,000 ballots. Meanwhile, in the EU, numerous polling stations were available across the

Eurozone, and these votes were critical in the â€œYesâ€ vote edging ahead of the â€œNoâ€ vote. As Maria Zakharova, Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman,Â noted:

â€œTheir project of integrating the country in the European Union failed to win decisive supportâ€,Â she said.

While Dmitry Peskov, Russian Presidential Spokesman, said:

â€œWhat we see is a mechanically hard-to-explain rate of increase in votes in favor of Sandu and in favor of those referendum participants who favored an EU orientationâ€

Even more concerning for Sandu and the EU, was the strong rejection of the EU by the region of Transnistria 62.5% of voters rejected the EU, which rose to 86.8% in Bulgarian-majority district of Taraclia, while the biggest rejection was from the population of the Gagauz Autonomous Region, where the â€œNoâ€ vote gained 94.8%.

If anyone in Chisinau or the EU is paying attention, they should be very reluctant to attempt to drive through the results of what is a fundamentally flawed process, as doing so could not only rekindle the conflict between the government and Transnistria, but also spread to Taraclia and the Gagauz autonomous region.

And it gets worse, when one looks at the campaign itself, as well as during the voting process.

The opposition was subjected to a campaign of harassment, arrest, and barring from running at all by Sanduâ€™s administration. The EU even went so far as toÂ sanction political leadersÂ of the Gaugaz autonomous region for being â€œpro-Russianâ€ during the build up to the elections. The EUâ€™s High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, the ever reprehensible Josep Borrell, stated:

â€œMoldova faces massive direct attempts from Russia to destabilize the country, as well as challenges arising from Russiaâ€™s war of aggression against Ukraine. This is a direct threat to a sovereign country, to its democratic life, to its path towards the European Union. The EU will continue providing all its support to the legitimate aspirations of the Moldovan people. Todayâ€™s listings are yet another contribution to the resilience of Moldova,â€

Moldovaâ€™s Internal Affairs

Which seems to me to be a rather nasty case of projection, given the way the EU has interfered in Moldovaâ€™s internal affairs. The bigger question is, what does this mean for other upcoming elections?

What is plain to see, is that EU and US rhetoric about democracy is little more thanÂ lipstick on a pig.Â We have already seen how in France, the incumbent president Macron hasÂ ignored the election results, and thereby, the will of the people, by refusing to allow the election winners, the left wing New Popular Front, to try and form a government, instead calling on the losers, in the form of Michel Barnier, an old school French rightist.

In Germany, it is no better, with the entire weight of the state directed at trying to crush the Eurosceptic party Alternative fur Deutschland, or AfD, which despite this has grown in popularity in the former East Germany,Â winningÂ the vote in Thuringia, and coming a close second in Saxony, despite an extremely un-level playing field.

Again, there is a particularly pronounced difference in attitude to Russia between East and West Germany, with East Germans being far more friendly to Russia than West Germans, which is not dependent on either the left or right of the political spectrum. This also gives lie to Cold War, and post-cold war propaganda about a â€œbrutal soviet occupationâ€ of East Germany by the USSR.

Moldovans as cannon fodder

The potential use of Moldovans as cannon fodder to prolong the agony of Ukraine is a real possibility. Moldova is not, by any means, a prosperous country. Given the hateful rhetoric of Sandu towards Russians at both a political and ethnic level, it is not hard to see her allowing the west to recruit large numbers of mercenaries for service in Ukraine.

Secondly, and far more ominous, is the possibility of a military attack on Transnistria, in order to â€œRestore Constitutional Orderâ€, evict the Russian peacekeeping force, and to take control of the tens of thousands of tons of ammunition stored in the region. Where did we hear such language before, Georgia and South Ossetia, back in 2008, and an American Election year to boot?

Russia has already drawn a red line, warning Moldova thatÂ any attack on Transnistria would be an attack on Russia, a warning previously issued to Georgia, and ignored by Saakashvili, in 2008. It should be noted that there wasÂ ample evidenceÂ that the West helped Saakashvili steal the election held January 5th, 2008, with disastrous results for Georgia.

Worst fears confirmed?

And now, all these concerns are coming to a head. The second round, held Sunday 3rdÂ November, seems to be a cynical replay of the suspected (now almost certain) vote rigging of the first.

It is obvious, after the defeat of western interests in Georgia, that the EU and US, as well as their puppets in Chisinau, would pull out all the stops to prevent a repeat.

Again, a pathetically small number of ballots, only 10,000, were sent to the polling station at the Moldovan embassy in Moscow, only enough for a tiny fraction of the eligible voters from the more than half a million living in Russia.

Again, as with the EU referendum, Sandu lost in Moldova itself, spectacularly so in Transnistria and the Gagauz Autonomous region and early results put her rival, Stoianoglu, in front.

Needless to say, western reporting has proclaimed the now expected mantra of â€œRussian interferenceâ€, conveniently ignoring numerous issues from both the first and second round, especially the disenfranchising of Moldovan citizens in Russia, whose numbers dwarf the winning margin.

If there is election interference from Russia, it is hard to see, while that of the US and EU is blatantly obvious. It also makes a mockery of US claims related to their own elections, which will occur on the 5thÂ of November, as well as the EU and US claims to be bastions of so-called democratic principles.

Already, media in Moldova itself have noted that she lost the election in Moldova, and are calling her â€œThe president of the diasporaâ€

Hold onto your hat, its going to be a wild ride!

The selective disenfranchisement of Moldovans in Russia and disproportionate EU support spotlight blatant manipulation, casting doubt on the legitimacy of â€œdemocraticâ€ aspirations trumpeted by the EU and U.S.

As Moldova teeters on the edge of internal conflict, the hypocrisy of Western interference is clear: democracy, it seems, only matters when it serves Western interests.

Hold onto your hats; Moldovaâ€™s political storm is far from over.

Why has the colour revolution in Moldova been called off?
by Stephen Karganovic
Whoever is endowed with even a modest capacity for political thinking will easily recognise the crooked game and the malignant rules by which it is being played.Â 

This question is rhetorical, of course, because such an event was never scheduled. The properly formulated question is why a classical colour revolution isnâ€™t now in progress in Moldova, after the fraudulent elections that recently took place in that country? TheÂ blatantly unfair â€œelectoralâ€ processÂ which resulted in Maia Sanduâ€™s alleged victory, critical to the collective West as its adventure in Ukraine turns into a Â debacle, meets all the criteria that should have triggered a â€œspontaneousâ€ colour revolution of the sort to which we had grown Â painfully accustomed.

But instead of facing civil turbulence for the dishonestly conducted 3 November Presidential election, on the contrary, fervent NATO and EU advocate and World Economic Forum Young Leader Sandu has been effusively praised and warmly congratulated on her bogus triumph.

At the same time, a concerted attempt to provoke regime change using classical colour revolution instruments is being made in Georgia. So far, it has fizzled out not for lack of trying but because of the political maturity shown by the Georgian people, who refused to take the bait. The pretext was the allegedly disputed parliamentary election in Georgia, the numerical result of which favouring the governing party (about 54%) and the opposition (45%) roughly corresponds to the contrastingly acceptable outcome in Moldova. What was the crucial difference? It was chiefly the geopolitical orientation of the respective governments that in those elections were up for public approval and the fact that the â€œnon-governmental organisationsâ€ which on command trigger regime change agitation are under the control of collective West intelligence agencies. Those agencies, in turn, and the governments whose instructions they execute, operate not with a factual but a utilitarian concept of what is a fair and free election. If as in Moldova the outcome serves collective Westâ€™s goals the election is fair; if as in Georgia it hinders them, it is fraudulent. Things are quiet in Moldova because local hirelings there were ordered not to stir up public discontent whilst in Georgia they were issued the opposite directive.

The other noteworthy difference is that the egregious irregularities of the electoral process in Moldova are amply documented whilstÂ allegations of similar misconduct in Georgia remain unsupported by any evidence whatsoever. But in the rules based order that hardly matters.

The completely utilitarian natureÂ of the assessments, by Western political institutions and media at least, of whether an election was legitimate or not, is demonstrated by the fact that the large segment of the Moldavian electorate residing in Russia, estimated to number about half a million, were effectively disenfranchised from the voting process. That was accomplished by drastically reducing to just a handful the number of Moldovan polling stations on Russian territory and making available only 10,000 paper ballots (curiously, it did not occur to anyone in Kishinev to use Dominion voting machines instead) to those Moldovan citizens residing in Russia who managed to overcome all obstacles in order to exercise their right to vote.

On the other hand, to stress the Moldovan regimeâ€™s strict adherence to â€œEuropean valuesâ€, no hindrances were placed in the way of the Moldovan diaspora in the European Union to take part in presidential elections in the country to which they may have a connection but where they do not reside. The Moldovan regimeâ€™s calculus was that the bulk of the Moldovans living and employedÂ in the EU have a private interest to not disrupt Moldovaâ€™s European Union accession process, however remote the prospects, because their legal residence in Europe and consequently the jobs they hold there enabling them to send remittances to relatives in impoverished Moldova depend on it. Unlike Moldovans residing in Russia, that segment of the Moldovan diaspora are highly motivated out of economic self-interest to vote for Maia Sandu and her pro-European policies. In the referendum to enshrine the goal of EU accession within the Moldovan Constitution, held under identically unequal conditions and simultaneously with the first round of presidential elections on 20 October, it was the vote of the Moldovan diaspora residing in the EU which enabled the proposed measure to prevail, albeit with a razor-thin margin of a fraction of a single percentage point.

In both instances, the majority of the people actually living in Moldova, who were to be most directly affected by the outcome of the voting, did not support either their governmentâ€™s pro-European Union policy or the election of Western puppet Maia Sandu to the presidency of their country. Results favourable to Western interests were achieved by resorting to corrupt practices and flagrant electoral engineering.

Understandably therefore a colour revolution was not engendered in the aftermath of the recent elections in Moldova, although all the objective conditions from Gene Sharpâ€™s playbook for launching one have been fulfilled. It suffices to recall in this regard one of the fundamental triggers which in the past have led to the overthrow of numerous legitimate governments that were indisposed to bow to the political dictates laid down by arrogant Western hegemons.

Sharpâ€™s doctrine prescribes that a close election result facilitates ideally the task of professionally organised and amply financed colour revolutionaries in need of a plausible pretext to mobilise and direct the clueless masses. That is because it lends credibility to the allegation of malfeasance levelled against of the targeted â€œregimeâ€ and fuels a sense of grievance among the populace, who supposedly were cheated out of effectively asserting their political will.

Such malfeasance is precisely what happened in Moldova but did not occur in Georgia. But Moldova is covered by a tight and, unlike Georgia, unsupervised network of Western financed â€œNGOs,â€ which by default exercise a monopoly on disinformation and â€œcivil societyâ€ activities. Consequently, in Moldova there is no movement to denounce flagrant systemic fraud or to challenge the legitimacy of the regime of foreign vassals who base their rule on the simulacrum of authority derived from that fraud. That is because, as we explained, the criteria that are applied always are unabashedly utilitarian; â€œconstructiveâ€ fraud as in Moldova, which serves the interests of the puppeteers, is always proper and irreproachable.

Honest elections, as in Georgia, which go against the grain always and irrespective of the factual matrix are denounced as fraudulent.

Whoever is endowed with even a modest capacity for political thinking will easily recognise the crooked game and the malignant rules by which it is being played.

Recentemente, vi Ã¨ andata in scena la farsa detta ''democrazia occidentale'' con una doppia votazione che ha avuto retroscena torbidi.

1

Il 20 ottobre, i cittadini residenti nel Paese e una parte di quelli all'estero hanno potuto votare il referendum sull'adesione all'Unione Europea, consistente nel consenso alla nota modifica costituzionale che permetterebbe il trasferimento di parte della sovranitÃ  nazionale al superorganismo burocratico dipendente dagli anglosassoni e impalcato a Bruxelles, Strasburgo, e altri luoghi.

Come accade in molti Paesi europei, un'ampia parte della popolazione non ha piÃ¹ fiducia nella politica, e solo la metÃ  dei cittadini ha esercitato il proprio diritto : ha votato solo il 50,72% â€“ 1.531.392 su 3.020.814 â€“ comunque sopra il quorum che era posto al 33,33% cioÃ¨ era sufficiente che votasse 1 cittadino su 3 perchÃ© il referendum fosse validato [5].
Il risultato Ã¨ stato il seguente [5]:

â— SÃ¬, 749.719, 50,35%;
â— No, 739.155, 49,65%.

1.1

All'interno della regione sottoposta de jure all'amministrazione di Kishinjov ( ĞšĞ¸ÑˆĞ¸Ğ½Ñ‘Ğ², trasl. anche Kishinev; nome rumeno : ChiÈ™inÄƒu, trasl. Chisinau ), vi sono almeno due situazioni particolari :

â— la Repubblica Moldava della Transnistria ( ĞŸÑ€Ğ¸Ğ´Ğ½ĞµÑÑ‚Ñ€Ğ¾Ğ²ÑĞºĞ°Ñ ĞœĞ¾Ğ»Ğ´Ğ°Ğ²ÑĞºĞ°Ñ Ğ ĞµÑĞ¿ÑƒĞ±Ğ»Ğ¸ĞºĞ° ) amministra il territorio oltre il fiume Nistro, e si Ã¨ proclamata indipendente all'inizio del 1990 mentre l'Unione Sovietica agonizzava e il movimento nazionalista spingeva all'emarginazione i gruppi etnici minoritari, tra cui i russi e altri slavi [6];
conseguentemente, iniziÃ² una guerra che durÃ² dal marzo al luglio del 1992, e venne risolta dall'intervento della 14Â° Armata comandata dal generale Alexander Lebed' ( ĞĞ»ĞµĞºÑĞ°Ğ½Ğ´Ñ€ Ğ˜Ğ²Ğ°Ğ½Ğ¾Ğ²Ğ¸Ñ‡ Ğ›ĞµĞ±ĞµĞ´ÑŒ )[7];
la Transnistria conta circa 450mila abitanti, di cui circa 130mila vivono nella capitale Tiraspol' ( Ğ¢Ğ¸Ñ€Ğ°ÑĞ¿Ğ¾Ğ»ÑŒ );

â— la Gagauzija ( Ğ“Ğ°Ğ³Ğ°ÑƒĞ·Ğ¸Ñ, trasl. anche Gagausia; nome gagauso : Gagauz Yeri, cirillico Ğ“Ğ°Ğ³Ğ°ÑƒĞ· Ğ•Ñ€Ğ¸; nome rumeno : GÄƒgÄƒuzia ), Ã¨ una regione autonoma nel sud della Moldavia, a ridosso del Budzhak ( Ğ‘ÑƒĞ´Ğ¶Ğ°Ğº; pron. ''bugiac'', trasl. anche Budjak, BudÅ¾ak; regione amministrata da Kiev, sita nell'oblast' di Odessa ), abitata principalmente da un gruppo etnico di origine turca e di religione cristiana ortodossa le cui origini non sono tutt'ora chiarite dagli storici, e la popolazione conta circa 130mila abitanti;
lo statuto Ã¨ stato promulgato nel 1994, in accordo con lo Stato moldavo; nel 2014 vennero promossi due referendum, sull'adesione della regione all'Unione doganale di Russia, Bielorussia, e Kazakhstan, e sull'indipendenza da Kishinjov in caso di entrata della Moldavia nell'Unione Europea, entrambi votati favorevolmente dalla maggioranza dei cittadini non considerati illegali dallo Stato moldavo [8][9].

Nella Transnistria sono stati pochi i cittadini che hanno votato il referendum ( appena 15.526 ) e si sono espressi nettamente per il No ( piÃ¹ di due elettori su tre )[10]:

â— SÃ¬, 4.816, 31,02%;
â— No, 10.710, 68,98%.

Nella Gaguzija c'Ã¨ stata una maggiore affluenza in linea con la media del Paese ( 57.847 voti ), ed un plebiscito per il No [10]:

â— SÃ¬, 2.985, 5,16%;
â— No, 54.862, 94,84%.

2

Il 20 ottobre, i cittadini residenti nel Paese e una parte di quelli all'estero hanno potuto anche votare il Presidente della Repubblica.
I principali candidati erano :

â— Maia Sandu [11][12], bimba di Schwab { [13][14][15][16]... } e presidente in carica, filo-UE e filo-NATO, con master in Economia ad Harvard e un periodo lavorativo come consigliere della Banca Mondiale, lesbica [17] sostenitrice delle leggi pro-LGBTQ+ [18], ha sospinto il SÃ¬ nel referendum sull'adesione alla maledetta UE e sÃ© stessa associando l'elezione presidenziale nella stessa data;

â— Alexander Stojanoglo ( ĞĞ»ĞµĞºÑĞ°Ğ½Ğ´Ñ€ Ğ”Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ‚Ñ€Ğ¸ĞµĞ²Ğ¸Ñ‡ Ğ¡Ñ‚Ğ¾ÑĞ½Ğ¾Ğ³Ğ»Ğ¾; nome rumeno : Alexandr Stoianoglo )[19][20], giurista gagauzo e filo-russo, giÃ  deputato e Procuratore generale della Moldavia dal 2019 al 2023, quando Ã¨ stato accusato di corruzione ed Ã¨ stato sollevato dall'incarico dalla Sandu ma senza avere un equo processo ed ottenendo successivamente un risarcimento pecuniario [21].

Nel primo turno ( 20 ottobre ) nessun candidato ha superato il 50% dei voti [22]:

â— Maia Sandu, 656.852, 42,49%;
â— Alexander Stoianoglo, 401.215, 25,95%.

Nel secondo turno ( 3 novembre ), Ã¨ stata confermata la prima posizione di Maia Sandu nonostante Stoianoglo abbia beneficiato dei voti dei candidati minori che erano quasi tutti filo-russi [22]:

â— Maia Sandu, 930.238, 55,35%;
â— Alexander Stoianoglo, 750.370, 44,65%.

La ''lesbica da combattimento'' potrÃ  continuare a sedere sulla poltrona del primo cittadino del piccolo Paese, e la sua vittoria Ã¨ stata riconosciuta dall'avversario [23].

3

Le votazioni moldave sono state macchiate da un grossolano episodio di ostruzionismo ai danni degli elettori del candidato filo-russo.
In entrambi i turni, Stoianoglo ha primeggiato sul territorio nazionale, poi il risultato Ã¨ stato ribaltato grazie ai voti dall'estero.
Nella Federazione Russa vivono e lavorano circa 500mila moldavi che solitamente possono votare in una quindicina di seggi organizzati allo scopo lungo i 12 fusi orari del grande Paese, ma stavolta lo Stato moldavo ha predisposto soltanto 2 ( due ) seggi, e le schede messe a disposizione erano solo 50mila [24].
Questo ha reso impossibile il voto a tantissimi moldavi che vivono e lavorano in Russia.
Al contrario, 200mila schede sono state spedite ai seggi organizzati negli uffici consolari nei Paesi dell'UE.
Ecco spiegato il sorpasso realizzato con i voti dall'estero.

3.1

Il retroscena sudicio Ã¨ stato raccontato dalla controinformazione { [24][25]... } e da Mirko Mussetti ( analista di Limes )[26], mentre Ã¨ stato completamente taciuto â€“ pertanto non smentito â€“ dai servili operatori del mainstream mediatico.

Come un disco rotto, la Sandu ha coperto rapidamente l'argomento delle irregolaritÃ  spargendo lagnanze su ''brogli'' e ''interferenze russe'' che sono state riprese senza alcuna verifica dai burocrati di Bruxelles e dai passaveline italiani e occidentali in genere.
Cito uno dei pochi articoli che, almeno, hanno posto in modo sfumato la complessitÃ  problematica della votazione [27]:

''Un paese diviso

Moldova, al referendum vince l'Europa. Presidenziali, avanti Sandu ma si va al ballottaggio

L'attuale Capo di Stato, filo-Ue, manca l'elezione al primo turno e denuncia ingerenze russe. Anche Bruxelles parla di interferenze e intimidazioni. Il Cremlino: mostrino le prove''.

GiÃ .
Dove sono le prove delle mitologiche ''interferenze e intimidazioni'' russe ?

Scorrendo il testo, leggiamo la sua buona educazione, eleganza, e rispetto dell'avversario politico [27]:

''Sandu: â€œI banditi vogliono tornare al potereâ€

[ ... ]. "Quello che Ã¨ successo ieri, ma anche negli ultimi anni, Ã¨ un attacco alla democrazia. I banditi che vogliono tornare al potere ad ogni costo volevano usare la democrazia come una debolezza" [ ... ].

Sui "banditi che vogliono tornare al potere" Sandu ha detto che "il loro obiettivo di comprare 30mila voti e 150mila persone pagate per votare dimostra che dobbiamo guardare attentamente a cosa Ã¨ andato storto e imparare da questo miserabile attacco alla nostra sovranitÃ . Sfortunatamente il sistema giudiziario non Ã¨ stato in grado di fare abbastanza per combattere la corruzione elettorale. Ma ora l'unico modo per difendere la nostra democrazia Ã¨ votare. Solo votando possiamo evitare un disastro".''

Quindi abbiamo offese e accuse gravi mosse contro l'avversario, che perÃ² non sono state comprovate dalla magistratura.
Fuffa.

3.2

Il comunicato del Portavoce principale per gli Affari esteri e la politica di Sicurezza ed Alto rappresentante dell'UE per la questione moldava, lo slovacco Peter Stano [28][29] Ã¨ stato scritto a regola d'arte per attaccare il Cremlino con le solite accuse non dimostrate.
Riporto un passaggio [30]:

''[ ... ].

I cittadini della Repubblica di Moldavia hanno fatto una scelta storica per ancorare il loro futuro all'interno dell'Unione europea, nonostante la massiccia interferenza e una campagna ibrida da parte della Russia e dei suoi delegati per minare il voto democratico in Moldavia.

L'Unione Europea condanna l'interferenza maligna senza precedenti della Russia nelle elezioni presidenziali e nel referendum costituzionale della Moldavia. Continueremo a sostenere la resilienza e i progressi della Repubblica di Moldavia nel suo percorso di adesione all'UE [ ... ].''

Bene.
Prove ?

Nessuna.

Solo l'ennesima buffonata della porcheria che Ã¨ diventata la ''democrazia occidentale''.
E sono abbastanza certo che, prima o poi, tutta questa sporcizia occidentale cadrÃ  addosso ai latori e ai popolani che passivamente l'accettano.

With the weather taking a colder turn today, the team, mascots included, nonetheless were warm and cozy within the four walls of Alt Media HQ studios at noonday. It was just another one of those â€˜birthday celebrationâ€™ days, when the crew feted Squeaky the Squirrelâ€™s beloved love of his life, Starbuck, on this her second birthday. The whole troop pitched in to present to her a platter full of the choicest nuts â€“ cashews and peanuts, among others, sweet rolls filled with strawberry, cherry and blueberry jams, big fat acorns. Starbuck was so overjoyed with her birthday gift that she eagerly shared the treats with her friends, but not before a superb lunch was served in the cafeteria. It was a veritable cornucopia of delights, as there were chicken burgers, fries, salads, cheese sticks, and lasagna, along with hummus, pita bread and kibbe balls. As for dessert, the birthday girl of the hour was presented with a rich apple pie, topped with pistachio ice cream. After lunch, the troops, led by Squeakyâ€™s best friend, Little Yozhik the Hedgehog, sang songs to Starbuck, while her blushing beau was deliriously happy with the ongoing proceedings. When the celebrations finally concluded, the group immediately returned to work, tackling the important geopolitical stories assigned for the day. A while later, unbeknownst to the rest of their colleagues and workmates, Squeaky and Starbuck managed to sneak away to the group lounge to exchange tender kisses, as their bushy tails were shaking and quivering with rapturous delight. The following brief report cum commentary is the first in a series of reports and is the result of a fruitful collaboration between two dear friends, independent journalists Octavian Popovici and Mina Dermenji. Popovici lives and works in ChiÈ™inÄƒu, Moldova, while Dermenji plies her trade in Comrat, the capital of the Gagauz Autonomous Region within southern Moldova. In this first report, they will concentrate their efforts solely on the recent election in Moldova â€˜wonâ€™ by the â€˜helicopteredâ€™ incumbent Pro-Western President, Maia Sandu, whose chief goal now is to â€˜integrateâ€™ Moldova within the EU geopolitical structure, thus aligning itself within the Euro-Atlanticist/NATO orbit. The report cum commentary will be uploaded on the Alt Media HQ studios website for the Thursday edition. This report is translated into English from the original Russian. 
â€œVremuri bune (Good times!), it was not! Apparently, incumbent President Maia Sandu â€˜wonâ€™ last Sundayâ€™s election in Moldova under a heavy cloud of suspicion of election manipulation, intimidation and voter fraud. The small impoverished Eastern European country was in the throes of a run-off of a two-round presidential election on Sunday, the 3rd of November. Moldovaâ€™s Central Election Committee â€œconfirmed Sanduâ€™s â€˜victoryâ€™ this past Monday, declaring that the pro-EU politician secured 55.35% of the total votes.â€ Meanwhile, â€˜the chief opposition party, the Socialists, led by Alexandr Stoianoglo received 44.65%, according to the official data released by the Central Election Committee.â€™ What is interesting is that, in the early voting, it appeared that Stoianoglo â€œwas leading by a slim margin, but the incumbent overtook him by midnight.â€ It seems that the suspicions of subterfuge and deceptive electoral stratagems were floating freely about in the midnight air over ChiÈ™inÄƒu. What exactly happened to change the fortunes of the rival Socialists?
 It is obvious what happened in this crooked election: Sanduâ€™s so-called â€˜victoryâ€™ was entirely the result of the Moldovan â€˜Diaspora.â€™ In other words, with over 90% of the votes counted, Sanduâ€™s leftist opponent Stoianoglo was in the lead, but â€œthe election was changed by the votes of the Moldovan diaspora living in the West.â€ In its statement on Monday, Stoianoglo and his Socialist Party cried foul, branding a â€œpresident of the diasporaâ€ who was really only recognized â€œby her sponsors and supporters abroad.â€ Furthermore, as of this moment, Stoianoglo and his party do not â€œrecognize the results of voting abroad, which, it said, led Sandu to victory.â€ According to the Socialist Partyâ€™s statements on the matter, â€œmore than 51% of Moldovans living inside the country supported Stoianoglo, making him â€œthe president of the people.â€ In fact, data from the Moldovan election authority has shown conclusively that Sandu received only 48.81% of the vote within Moldova itself, while her opponent gathered a slightly higher share, at 51.19%.â€
The Socialists also described numerous egregious violations committed by the authorities during the voting process. These violations would include â€œranging from blocking votersâ€™ access to the polling stations and illegal electoral agitation to the disappearance of ballot boxes to outright falsifications.â€ On account of violations such as these, â€œrecent presidential electionsâ€¦cannot be considered a free and democratic expression of the will of the people.â€ The Socialist Party was not the only entity to take great issue with these laundered electoral result. The Kremlin â€œhas refused to fully acknowledgeâ€ the election results. Kremlin spokesman, Dmitry Peskov stated categorically and for the record that the incumbent Sandu cannot be seen as the legitimate holder of the presidential office, emphasizing that the â€œmajority of people within Moldova itself did not vote for her.â€ Peskov was quick to criticize the whole Moldovan electoral framework, pointing out â€œsignificant procedural irregularities that hindered the voting rights of its citizens residing in Russia.â€ Maria Zakharova, Russiaâ€™s Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, stated that, â€œdespite an estimated 500,000 Moldovans living in Russia, only a handful of polling stations were made available to them.â€ Even in the self-governing Transnistrian Moldovan Republic, â€˜the number of polling stations were reduced from forty-four to thirty.â€™ In sharp contrast to this reality, â€œover 200 polling sites were set up in Western states, which allowed for much higher accessibility among the diaspora there.â€ This obvious disparity â€œcompromises the transparencyâ€ of the vote immediately questioning its legitimacy in the eyes of the world. In other words, these â€œelection were neither free nor fair.â€
The Socialists have now vowed to â€œdevelop a strategy to depoliticize state institutions and ensure equal conditions in electoral campaignsâ€ together with other political parties, in order to defend the interests, who had â€œexpressed their will and made a free choice.â€ Now, Moldovan police claimed that there were â€œa total of 225 violations reported during the voting, ranging from ballot damage to illegal political agitation and voter bribing,â€ and that â€˜Russia itself was the culprit.â€™ Predictably, Sandu and her EU-financed cohorts in the government claimed that there were â€œcriminal groupsâ€ colluding with â€œforeign forces hostile to our national interests,â€ thus surreptitiously pointing a finger at Russia. Obviously, Sandu has indulged in a little projection herself at this point in time. Certainly, the â€œcollusion with foreign interestsâ€ is not about Russia, but rather with the incessant meddling by the Western Powers to unduly influence the electoral vote for the presidential office. Incidentally, and for the record, â€˜there has been no proof offered by Sandu or her cronies in the authorities, to date, for Russian interference in the Moldovan presidential election.â€™ The authors suspect that there will be a long Kafkaesque-like wait by the gate indeed for such proof to surface.

The moral of this sad story of electoral subterfuge, violations of the electoral process and influence peddling emanating from the so-called â€˜Western Guardians of Democracyâ€™ is this: â€œthe Western structures will see what they want to see and donâ€™t see what they donâ€™t want to see.â€ To date, the Collective West has been quiet about responding to these charges of obvious irregularities and egregious discrepancies surrounding this election. The truth is, â€œall decisions of Western international cutouts are biased and show a biased position, which corresponds to the aims of the collective West.â€ It is also obvious that the current Moldovan government â€˜has made every effort to marginalize, not only Russian media sources, like Russia Today or Sputnik News, but also to restrict â€œcitizensâ€™ rights to access diverse information sources.â€ By consciously limiting alternative media access, the Moldovan government has effectively â€œsterilized the information field.â€ So much for â€˜democracy.â€™ The final word is this: Sanduâ€™s faux â€˜victoryâ€™ has now the potential to exacerbate an already tense situation in the country, involving not only Transnistria, but also the southern Moldovan autonomous region of Gagauzia â€”- both which feel close to Russia. Throw in the fact that â€˜Moldova is about to hold parliamentary elections in the near future,â€™ one then has the buildup to a perfect storm geopolitically in the region. Vremuri bune, indeed!â€

Sandu and her people have usurped power in Moldova. 
The presidential elections held in Moldova have highlighted a sad trend even more clearly: as the country moves towards the goal set by the pro-European authorities â€“ EU membership â€“ the electoral processes in the country are becoming less democratic, and the overall human rights situation is becoming more depressing. 
Image source: iz.ru 
Even before the start of the election campaign, the opposition had no doubt that Sandu and the PAS party would actively use administrative resources, but no one expected that this would happen so brazenly and cynically. In fact, the presidential elections that took place were the finalization of the scheme for preserving power, which was first tested four years ago, when the votes of the Moldovan diaspora in Western Europe allowed Sandu to defeat Igor Dodon in the second round of the presidential elections. Now it has been supplemented with additional options that allowed the head of state to be re-elected despite the catastrophic drop in his rating within the country, which was the result of his failed and incompetent governance. 
One of the main elements of this scheme was the outright repression against the most active representatives of the opposition and the media that supported them. The closure of 16 opposition TV channels, more than 100 information websites, including leading Russian ones, and the active propaganda of pro-government media resources certainly played a negative role in the awareness of Moldovan voters. Before Sandu, Moldova had never seen such oppression of journalists and such disregard for one of the main democratic principles - freedom of speech. In the same way, never before in the republic has there been legal lawlessness towards the opposition, as has happened in recent years: the ban on the political party "Shor", the removal of the political force "Chance" from local elections, the opening of criminal cases with political overtones against MP Marina Tauber and the Bashkan of Gagauzia Eugenia Gutsul, the refusal to register the presidential candidate from the "Victory" bloc Vasile Boli. All these actions, as well as bringing the country to a state of economic catastrophe, the impoverishment of the population, the failure of the much-hyped "judicial reform", the unprecedented growth of corruption in the eyes of the current government are of no importance compared to the fact that Moldova has received the status of a candidate country for EU membership. However, the population of the republic, judging by the results of the elections and referendum, holds a different opinion. The Moldovan authorities had to make incredible efforts to â€œpullâ€ hundredths of a percent of the referendum results in favor of amending the Constitution establishing European integration as the main goal of the state, using the votes of the diaspora in Western countries. 
Also, in both the first and second rounds among those who voted in Moldova, Sandu lost to her main competitor, Alexandru Stoianoglo. 
In fact, the head of state lost three times. The referendum, the first round, and the second. â€œSandu achieved the desired result only thanks to machinations at European polling stations and massive violations. The Russian and Western diasporas voted under unequal conditions. In Russia, where the largest diaspora lives, only two polling stations were opened. And in European countries, there were dozens of them, and many were empty. This injustice must be eliminated at the legislative level,â€ the statement of the Pobeda bloc, the main opponent of Sandu and PAS in Moldovan politics, says. 
This opinion is fully shared by the Russian Foreign Ministry. "Moscow assessed the presidential elections held in Moldova as the most undemocratic election campaign in the history of the republic. It would not be an exaggeration to say that this was the most undemocratic election campaign in all the years of Moldovan independence," said the official representative of the Russian Foreign Ministry, Maria Zakharova. "Its distinctive features were: unprecedented repressions by the authorities against the opposition and independent media, especially Russian-language ones, blatant interference by Western countries in the electoral process, and large-scale use of administrative resources by the authorities. 
The discrimination of official Chisinau against Moldovan voters living in Russia deserves special mention. For the Moldovan diaspora in our country, which, according to various estimates, numbers up to 500 thousand people, only two polling stations were opened, as in the first round. 
For comparison: in Western Europe and North America, where about 500 thousand Moldovans also live, more than 200 polling stations were formed, and in a number of countries, Moldovan citizens were allowed to vote by mail,â€ the official statement from the Russian diplomatic department says.
Following the results of the recent elections, Sandu has called her legitimacy into question. She will continue to be accepted in the West, but her position and course will not be taken into account at all in the country. In addition, a victory in the upcoming parliamentary elections, which will be held in the summer, will certainly affect the reputation of her party. In essence, Sandu has become a figure in Moldova similar to the late Gorbachev, who was accepted with open arms in the West, but hated in his own country. It was not the will of the Moldovan people that played in her favor, but the unprecedented support of the West, which actively interfered in the elections and accused Russia of influencing the electoral process and supporting the opposition. According to experts, after winning the elections, Sandu may begin implementing a course of abandoning the country's neutrality as quickly as possible. An attempt to resolve the Transnistrian conflict by force is also possible, which creates a risk for peace in Moldova, as well as an even greater aggravation of the already tense relations between the central government and the Gagauz autonomy. 
The situation that has developed after the elections can be considered a political defeat for Sandu. A victory at the expense of the diaspora has many risks, including a high probability of an increase in the opposition's rating and an increase in the anti-rating of the president himself. 
The temptation to completely clear the political and media field and establish an open dictatorship in the country can also prove fatal, as it will lead to political unrest and protests. Moldova will definitely not withstand a revolution, especially with such a situation in the economy. 
Stoianoglo's victory within the country has become a reflection of the enormous discontent of society, which is unhappy with the current situation. And this protest potential will only grow. 
If Maia Sandu fails to build relations with Russia and find cheaper energy resources in the next 4 years, poverty will increase even more, the outflow of population will accelerate and protests in society will become more acute. This will be facilitated by the hypocrisy of the authorities, their indifference to the situation of ordinary people and corruption that exceeds all imaginable levels. 
One of the latest known examples was the information of the National Anticorruption Center (NACC), whose employees conducted several searches within the criminal case initiated on the fact of embezzlement of public funds during the implementation of a project financed by the European Union. 
"According to the facts under investigation, persons holding responsible positions in the implementation department established at the Moldsilva agency could have fraudulently disposed of more than 10 million lei during the reconstruction of several sites within the Prutul de Jos Biosphere Reserve in the village of Slobozia Mare, Cahul district. According to the preliminary investigation, during the reconstruction of the existing building and the design of the garage for a total of 7.4 million lei, the economic agent used only 3.7 million lei, and the remaining difference of about 4 million lei was stolen," the NAC press release says. This information confirms in the best possible way that the current regime will try to prolong its existence and will cling to power with all its might. Sandu and her team understand that they have lost popularity among the people and will not be able to win the parliamentary elections honestly. Therefore, there is no doubt that they will try to falsify them in the same way as the presidential elections.

The â€œmoral guardiansâ€ see what they want to see and donâ€™t see what they donâ€™t want to see             
By Vladimir Shapovalov, Associate Professor of the Department of Comparative Political Science at Moscow State Institute of International Relations (MGIMO)
Moldovaâ€™s incumbent President Maia Sandu and former Prosecutor General Alexandr Stoianoglo, attend election debates  Â© Sputnik /                 Sputnik
Last weekend’s second round of elections in Moldova ended with a victory for incumbent pro-Western President Maia Sandu. With 90% of the votes counted, her leftist opponent Aleksandr Stoianoglo was in the lead, but the election was changed by the votes of the Moldovan diaspora living in the West.
The results show that Sandu does not enjoy the confidence of Moldovan citizens at home. She received fewer votes than her opponent from people who actually live in the country.
The outcomes of both rounds of the presidential election in Moldova, as well as the vote on the referendum on EU integration, took place in a context of severe pressure on the opposition, the use of administrative resources, cynical anti-Russian rhetoric and shameless interference in Moldova’s internal affairs by NATO states.
Arbitrariness appeared in the form of a decision to reduce the number of polling stations on the territory of Russia. It is known that only two were opened, both in Moscow.
And the number of ballot papers submitted to these polling stations was only 10,000. As a result, all Moldovan citizens who were not among these 10,000 were unable to vote. The number of polling stations on the territory of the self-governing Transnistrian Moldovan Republic was also reduced. From forty-four to thirty. And this became another important factor influencing the electoral process.
                                                           Read more             Was this small post-Soviet countryâ€™s EU referendum stolen?                
We are talking about deliberate obstacles to the exercise of the right to vote placed in front of certain categories of Moldovan citizens â€“ those who, from the point of view of Western curators, could pose a threat to Sandu’s chances.
Of course, we cannot talk about democracy in this case, because the basic principles of democratic elections were violated. In fact, we are talking about discrimination on political and other grounds.
But let’s get real: Western structures see what they want to see and don’t see what they don’t want to see.
Therefore, all decisions of Western international observation cutouts are biased and show a biased position, which corresponds to the aims of the collective West.
Violations during both the first and second rounds of the Moldovan presidential election went unnoticed. 
The Moldovan president is not the only key figure in the Moldovan political system, but in the current circumstances Sandu’s victory will lead to a further escalation of tensions in relations with Russia. This victory will be accompanied by increased information attacks and tensions in relations with Transnistria, and provocations against the southern Moldovan region of Gagauzia â€“ which feels close to Moscow â€“ are also possible.
And Moldova is about to hold parliamentary elections that are likely to exacerbate its political crisis.

This article was first published by the online newspaper Gazeta.ru and was translated and edited by the RT team

LA RUSSIA NON RICONOSCE IL VOTO IN MOLDAVIA

E' stato talmente parossistico il broglio elettorale avvenuto in Moldavia che la Russia, che solitamente si astiene dal parlare sui processi elettorali altrui, ha deciso di non riconoscerlo.
Effettivamente la serva del WEF, Maia Sandu, Ã¨ stata sconfitta in patria ma ha ribaltato l'esito delle elezioni con il voto all'estero ma attenzione: di fatto la Sandu ha permesso di votare solo ai moldavi residenti in EU. Ai 500.000 moldavi residenti in Russia ha fatto arrivare solo 10.000 schede elettorali.
In questo modo sono state truccate le elezioni e di fatto la Russia non le riconosce.
Buona fortuna alla Eu, alla Nato e alla Sandu a governare un paese in questo modo.
 TERZO MILLENNIO

The â€œmoral guardiansâ€ see what they want to see and donâ€™t see what they donâ€™t want to see             
By Vladimir Shapovalov, Associate Professor of the Department of Comparative Political Science at Moscow State Institute of International Relations (MGIMO)
Moldovaâ€™s incumbent President Maia Sandu and former Prosecutor General Alexandr Stoianoglo, attend election debates  Â© Sputnik /                 Sputnik
Last weekend’s second round of elections in Moldova ended with a victory for incumbent pro-Western President Maia Sandu. With 90% of the votes counted, her leftist opponent Aleksandr Stoianoglo was in the lead, but the election was changed by the votes of the Moldovan diaspora living in the West.
The results show that Sandu does not enjoy the confidence of Moldovan citizens at home. She received fewer votes than her opponent from people who actually live in the country.
The outcomes of both rounds of the presidential election in Moldova, as well as the vote on the referendum on EU integration, took place in a context of severe pressure on the opposition, the use of administrative resources, cynical anti-Russian rhetoric and shameless interference in Moldova’s internal affairs by NATO states.
Arbitrariness appeared in the form of a decision to reduce the number of polling stations on the territory of Russia. It is known that only two were opened, both in Moscow.
And the number of ballot papers submitted to these polling stations was only 10,000. As a result, all Moldovan citizens who were not among these 10,000 were unable to vote. The number of polling stations on the territory of the self-governing Transnistrian Moldovan Republic was also reduced. From forty-four to thirty. And this became another important factor influencing the electoral process.
                                                           Read more             Was this small post-Soviet countryâ€™s EU referendum stolen?                
We are talking about deliberate obstacles to the exercise of the right to vote placed in front of certain categories of Moldovan citizens â€“ those who, from the point of view of Western curators, could pose a threat to Sandu’s chances.
Of course, we cannot talk about democracy in this case, because the basic principles of democratic elections were violated. In fact, we are talking about discrimination on political and other grounds.
But let’s get real: Western structures see what they want to see and don’t see what they don’t want to see.
Therefore, all decisions of Western international observation cutouts are biased and show a biased position, which corresponds to the aims of the collective West.
Violations during both the first and second rounds of the Moldovan presidential election went unnoticed. 
The Moldovan president is not the only key figure in the Moldovan political system, but in the current circumstances Sandu’s victory will lead to a further escalation of tensions in relations with Russia. This victory will be accompanied by increased information attacks and tensions in relations with Transnistria, and provocations against the southern Moldovan region of Gagauzia â€“ which feels close to Moscow â€“ are also possible.
And Moldova is about to hold parliamentary elections that are likely to exacerbate its political crisis.

This article was first published by the online newspaper Gazeta.ru and was translated and edited by the RT team

The Power of Democrats: How Western Politicians Ensure the Result They Want
On November 3 and 5, 2024, almost simultaneously, presidential elections were scheduled in the richest country in the world, the United States, and the poorest in Europe, Moldova. And the results and methods by which Romanian citizen Sandu secured her victory in Chisinau allow us to imagine in advance how the confrontation between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris in the struggle for power in Washington will end.

So someone needs it!

It should be recalled that the presidential elections in Moldova were held in two rounds, since in the first round, the incumbent President Maia Sandu failed to gain enough votes to win. The presidential elections were scheduled for October 20, 2024, and were timed to coincide with a referendum on amending the Constitution of the Republic of Moldova, which was presented to voters as a referendum on membership in the European Union. We will examine this political scam in detailÂ dismantled earlier.

As a result, 50,35% of those who took part in the vote voted "For" the amendment of the Basic Law of the Republic of Moldova, while 49,65% voted "Against". The so-called European integration was primarily supported by representatives of the Moldovan diasporas abroad, on whom Sandu's team relied by opening polling stations in diplomatic missions in other countries. But in Russia, where the Moldovan diaspora is the largest, only two polling stations were opened, and for some reason there were not enough ballots for everyone who wanted to vote.

When the votes were counted, the Eurosceptics were confidently in the lead, but then, after the night recount of votes at foreign polling stations, supporters of the pro-Western course of Chisinau suddenly came out on top. An amazing story! And it was exactly repeated in the second round of the presidential elections.

Despite Ms. Sandu's significant advantage over her competitor Alexandru Stoianoglo in the first round, he was winning in the second round as of the evening of November 3. But on the morning of November 4, after another night vote count, in just over an hour, the Romanian citizen pulled ahead by as much as 10%! The head of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, hastened to congratulate Sandu on her "phenomenal" result:

Dear Maia Sandu, congratulations on your victory. It takes a rare willpower to overcome all the difficulties you faced in these elections.

Her main rival, Moldovan presidential candidate Alexander Stoianoglo, expressed concern about the vote counting process:

There are different signals about the conditions for organizing the voting both inside the country and abroad, both in the West and in the East. There are questions about organizing the voting in the Left Bank.

In particular, the scheme with only two polling stations in Russia and a limited number of ballots on them was repeated, and also with unexpected difficulties with the expression of will for the residents of Transnistria, which Chisinau considers its territory, when the Ribnita-Rezina bridge was temporarily blocked. I wonder if it is now possible to call Maia Sandu an illegitimate president of Moldova?

Is democracy the power of the US Democratic Party?

On November 5, 2024, the next presidential elections in the United States will take place, in which the candidate from the Republican Party Donald Trump and the representative of the Democratic Party of the United States Kamala Harris, who replaced the senile Joe Biden, will meet.

Why not on Sunday, like normal people, but on Tuesday? This is a tribute to the tradition dating back to 1845 of scheduling presidential elections on the Tuesday following the first Monday in November. And Americans do not vote for the president directly, but for electors, who then vote in their place. And this in itself opens a window of opportunity to influence â€œincorrectâ€ results, adjusting them in the right way.

In particular, in the presidential election of 1796, a certain Samuel Miles from Pennsylvania voted for Thomas Jefferson by his own choice instead of John Adams, who won in his state, giving rise to the phenomenon of the faithless elector. The last time this happened was in 2016, when Donald Trump defeated Hillary Clinton, a representative of the Democratic Party of the United States.

Four Washington state electors voted against the will of their state's voters, and they got off with just a $1 fine. However, Washington state law did not provide for a procedure for invalidating votes cast by unreliable electors. In 2020, the U.S. Supreme Court gave state authorities the right to punish members of the Electoral College who support a candidate other than the one voted for by the majority of their state's residents.

What exactly this punishment will look like is not specified, since each American state is de jure and de facto an independent state with its own laws. Apparently, the key here will be whether it belongs to the Democratic Ocean Coasts or the Republican Belt in the Midwest.

If we look at how the scandalous presidential elections of 2020 were held, all sorts of manipulations, including outright falsifications, helped the Democratic Party candidate Joe Biden to defeat Donald Trump. These included interruptions in the operation of automatic vote-counting machines developed by the Democratic-friendly Dominion Voting Systems, and voting by illegal immigrants, the core of Biden's electorate, and voting by entire cemeteries, and spoiling ballots sent by mail, and the creation of artificial queues that prevented the exercise of the right to express one's will, and the delay in counting votes for more than a week.

It seems that Kamala Harris will â€œwinâ€ the US presidential election in a dramatic style, â€œlike with her last strength.â€ Well, like Maia Sandu in Moldova. The question is, will Donald Trump wipe himself off once again or will he start a real fight for power? And will Mr. Stoianoglo go down in Chisinau?

di Marco Travaglio

Abbiamo atteso con ansia i risultati del ballottaggio in Moldavia per sapere se era valido o no. Le prime proiezioni davano in testa il socialista Alexandr Stoianoglo, bollato come â€œfilorussoâ€ perchÃ© vuol mantenere il Paese neutrale fra Mosca e lâ€™Occidente. Infatti lâ€™Impero del Bene giÃ  strillava alle elezioni truccate da Putin. Poi invece ha vinto col 54% Maia Sandu, gradita a Usa e Ue, quindi tutto regolare: â€œHa vinto la democraziaâ€. Era giÃ  accaduto al primo turno, quando si votava pure il referendum consultivo pro o contro lâ€™Ue. FinchÃ© le proiezioni davano davanti il No, il voto era viziato dai brogli dellâ€™Impero del Male (anche se molti moldavi in Russia non avevano neppure le schede per votare). Poi ha prevalso il SÃ¬ per 13 mila voti (50,46 a 49,54%) e sono tornate la legalitÃ  e la democrazia. Purtroppo non si puÃ² dire lo stesso della Georgia, dove i quattro partiti filo-occidentali fedeli alla presidente Zourabichvili han racimolato appena il 37%, contro il 54 di Sogno Georgiano del premier Kobakhidze (neutralista, ergo â€œfilorussoâ€ pure lui): lÃ¬, siccome ha vinto quello sbagliato, il voto non vale, anche se lâ€™Ocse non ha rilevato irregolaritÃ  e il riconteggio ha confermato la disfatta dei Buoni per mano dei Cattivi. La Zourabichvili, che non Ã¨ neppure georgiana ma francese, anzichÃ© inchinarsi alla sovranitÃ  popolare, ha chiamato la gente in piazza per ribellarsi e chiedere di rivotare, col sostegno delle famose democrazie Usa e Ue, che accettano i risultati elettorali solo se piacciono a loro. Se vince il candidato sbagliato, le elezioni sono truccate e si rivota finchÃ© non vince chi decidono loro.

Sono gli stessi che accusano preventivamente Trump di avere lâ€™intenzione di non riconoscere lâ€™eventuale sconfitta, come giÃ  quattro anni fa con lâ€™assalto a Capitol Hill. E intanto fanno la stessa cosa in Georgia ed erano pronti a farla anche in Moldavia, se al referendum avesse vinto il No e se la Sandu avesse perso le Presidenziali. Anche fra i golpisti, ci sono quelli buoni e quelli cattivi. Come per le fake news. Lâ€™altro giorno Trump ha attaccato la guerrafondaia Liz Cheney, degna figlia di suo padre, schierata con la Harris: â€œHa sempre voluto mandare la gente in guerra, se fosse per lei saremmo in guerra con 50 Paesi: mettiamola davanti a un fucile che le spara addosso e vediamo come si sente. Un discorso che avrebbe potuto fare Gino Strada. Ma tutti i media dellâ€™Harris Bar hanno scritto che Trump istigava a fucilare la Cheney e un procuratore idiota ha pure aperto unâ€™inchiesta. Le balle dei buoni non sono fake news: sono dogmi di fede.

Laut offiziellen Angaben errang Maia Sandu, die amtierende Präsidentin des Landes, bei der Stichwahl am Wochenende 55,33 Prozent der Stimmen. Ihr Rivale, der ehemalige Generalstaatsanwalt Alexandr Stoianoglo, verlor mit 44,67 Prozent.
Schor zeigte sich überzeugt, dass Sandu den Sieg ausschließlich dank Manipulationen in den Wahllokalen in Europa und Verstößen bei der Abstimmung erreicht habe. Praktisch habe sie jedoch â€œdreimal verloren, und zwar bei dem EU-Referendum, dem ersten Wahlgang und bei der Stichwahlâ€. Die russische und westliche Diaspora seien während der Wahl benachteiligt worden.
In Russland, wo bis zu 500.000 Moldawier leben, seien nur zwei Wahllokale geöffnet gewesen, betonte Schor. Gleichzeitig habe es in den europäischen Ländern Dutzende Wahlräume gegeben, die meisten davon seien leer gewesen. Diese Ungleichheit müsse gesetzlich beseitigt werden. Im Inland habe Sandu die Stichwahl verloren, daher müsse sie zurücktreten, forderte Schor:

â€œWir sind überzeugt, dass jeder Tag von Maia Sandus Amtszeit eine Machtusurpation ist. Sie ist keine Präsidentin, sondern Betrügerin. Sandu hat im Inland verloren und muss weg.â€

Chisinau denies hundreds of thousands of Moldovans in Russia right to vote â€” Kremlin
 
Dmitry Peskov stressed that the Moldovan election was "neither democratic nor fair" and was "fraught with electoral manipulations"
 
MOSCOW, November 5. /TASS/. Hundreds of thousands of Moldovans living in Russia were denied the right to vote in the Moldovan presidential election, which could not fail to impact the results, Russian Presidential Spokesman Dmitry Peskov told the media. 
 
"We can objectively assess these elections. There are hundreds of thousands of Moldovan citizens living in Russia â€” not just tens of thousands, but several hundred thousand. These citizens were not given the opportunity to exercise their right to vote," Peskov pointed out. 
 
"In fact, a large portion of the population of the country was unable to vote, unlike Moldovan citizens working in European countries. Naturally, this could not have had no effect on the election results, which, therefore, cannot be considered legitimate," Peskov added. 
 
He stressed that the Moldovan election was "neither democratic nor fair" and was "fraught with electoral manipulations." Peskov also pointed out that a majority of Moldovaâ€™s population did not vote for President Maia Sandu, signaling a serious societal divide that "will inevitably continue." 
 
"As for the current Moldovan leadership, it appears they will continue on the same path. So far, they have shown no interest in improving relations with our country. On the contrary, they have been the architects of policies aimed at curtailing interaction with us, pressuring our media, sterilizing the information space in their country, and blocking any information flows from Russia. This, of course, is a clear violation of the rights of their citizens to access diverse information," Peskov said. 
 
He also addressed the accusations from Moldovan President Maia Sanduâ€™s national security advisor, Stanislav Secrieru, who claimed that Moscow allegedly interfered in the presidential election runoff. 
 
"There was no interference. There could not have been any. We have no presence in Moldova. Even the Moldovan opposition faces illegal attacks and pressure. There have been arrests, searches, and much more. What does Russia have to do with all this? This is the result of the undemocratic and authoritarian policies of the current Moldovan leadership," Peskov noted. "We were not involved in the organization of voting within Russia either. The fact that only two polling stations were opened was a decision made by the Moldovan authorities. It has nothing to do with us." 
 
"Therefore, of course, we hear such baseless accusations, but we have never heard any credible reproaches based on verifiable information," the Kremlin spokesman stressed. 
 
Moldovan election
 
On Sunday, Moldova held the second round of its presidential elections. According to the Central Election Commission (CEC), after reviewing 100% of the vote count, Maia Sandu received 55.33% of the vote, while her opponent, former Prosecutor General Alexander Stoianoglo, garnered 44.67%. At polling stations within Moldova, Stoianoglo led with 51% after all votes were counted. The opposition, represented by the Party of Socialists of the Republic of Moldova, called Sandu an illegitimate president, recognized only by her "foreign sponsors and patrons." Sandu declared victory, while Stoianoglo urged his supporters to remain calm.

Le président du Rassemblement National Jordan Bardella n’a pas manqué de faire ce rapprochement et de dénoncer: «il est la nouvelle victime de la barbarie quotidienne qui s’abat sur la France».
Le 1er novembre, à Poitiers, un mineur de 15 ans est mort après avoir reçu une balle en pleine tête lors dâ€™une fusillade. Quatre autres jeunes, dont deux de moins de 16 ans, ont été blessés par balles dans cette rixe sur fond de trafic de drogue, qui aurait impliqué «50 à 60 personnes», selon une source policière citée par la presse française.
A Rennes, le 2 novembre, c’est un jeune homme de 19 ans qui a été poignardé à mort dans le quartier de Pontchaillou. Le même jour, un autre homme de 29 ans a été poignardé lors dâ€™une rixe en début de soirée dans le centre-ville.
Dans la nuit du 2 au 3 novembre à Dijon, en Côte-d’Or, c’est un jeune homme qui a été passé à tabac et «laissé pour mort», selon sa mère, «pour au final un téléphone et un portefeuille». 

Enfin, le début de la semaine a également été marqué par des faits de violences. A Ozoir-la-Ferrière, en région parisienne, 4 personnes ont été blessées à coups de hache, dont deux grièvement, lors dâ€™une rixe dans le RER E. L’un d’entre eux a une main tranchée et lâ€™autre a été touché à la tête avec cerveau apparent, ont rapporté des médias franciliens.

Maia Sandu has become the â€œpresident of the diaspora,â€ the Party of Socialists has said in a statement
FILE PHOTO. Â©                 Global Look Press / IMAGO / Fotostand / Nieweler
Moldova’s biggest opposition party has challenged the results of the presidential runoff held on Sunday. The Party of Socialists said in a statement on Monday it does not recognize incumbent leader Maia Sandu’s victory and declared its own candidate and Sandu’s rival, Alexandr Stoianoglo, to be the “real winner.”
The nation’s Central Election Committee confirmed Sandu’s victory earlier on Monday.
The pro-Eu politician secured 55.35% of the votes, it said. Stoianoglo got 44.65%, according to official data. Early results suggested Stoianoglo was leading by a slim margin but the incumbent overtook him by midnight and the gap between the two kept growing. Moldovans living in Western Europe were instrumental in Sandu’s victory in both the first round of the presidential elections in October and in Sunday’s runoff, according to the media.
In its statement on Monday, the Socialists branded Sandu a “president of the diaspora” who was only recognized by “her sponsors and supporters abroad.” The party also said that it does not recognize the results of the voting abroad, which, it said, led Sandu to victory.
                                                           Read more             Moldovaâ€™s Pro-EU president awarded second term                
According to the party’s statements, more than 51% of Moldovans living inside the country supported Stoianoglo, making him “the president of the people.” The Socialists also pointed to what they described as numerous violations committed by the authorities during the vote. Alleged irregularities ranged from blocking voters’ access to the polling stations and illegal electoral agitation to the disappearance of ballot boxes and outright falsifications. 
“Recent presidential elections … cannot be considered a free and democratic expression of the will of the people,” the statement said.
The party then vowed to develop a “strategy to depoliticize state institutions and ensure equal conditions in electoral campaigns” together with other political parties and defend the interests of all Moldovans, who had “expressed their will and made a free choice.” It still stopped short of announcing any specific measures in the wake of the vote.
Moldovan police said that a total of 225 violations were reported during the voting, ranging from ballot damage to illegal political agitation and voter bribing. Prior to the vote, Moldovan authorities claimed they’d found evidence of Russian attempts to interfere with the vote. The Kremlin strongly rejected these accusations.
After the first round, Sandu claimed that there was “clear evidence” of criminal groups supposedly colluding with “foreign forces hostile to our national interests” to meddle into the elections. Moscow then demanded she provide evidence to support her claims.

Abbiamo atteso con ansia i risultati del ballottaggio in Moldavia per sapere se era valido o no.
